option.name: title_text
option.value: A Thematic Analysis of the Student Perspectives Towards Online Learning

string_table.name: pxabnsnfns11111100111
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.

slidelink.displaytext: Thematic Analysis of the JISC Free-Text Data

search.slidetext: total responses 512 # of faculties 4 # of questions analysed 3 question 1 what aspect of online learning, if any, has been most positive for you? question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? question 2 what aspect of online learning, if any, has been most negative for you? methods, limitations, and important considerations

total responses 512 # of faculties 4 # of questions analysed 3 braun & clarke’s (2021) framework for performing a thematic analysis was employed in analysing the responses provided by jisc. as such, i familiarised myself with the data and generated the initial codes before identifying the preliminary themes. these themes were then further reviewed and revised accordingly to better reflect the student responses. in terms of limitations and considerations, no member checking was performed, therefore, we need to be careful when making conclusions regarding the accuracy of the interpretations, especially since the wording of the questions can easily be misconstrued (e.g., “effective” can mean different for individuals, “most positive” does not mean that the chosen aspect is necessarily “positive” but rather considered to be the “most positive, all things considering”). second, there is a huge discrepancy in the number of responses from each school with the school of transport studies only accounting for approximately 5% of the responses, and school of earth and environment for 46%, thus, any generalisations made from this set of data must take this into consideration. lastly, n in this thematic analysis is counted as number of responses instead of respondents for a couple of reasons: 1) some respondents gave multiple answers, and 2) avoidance of duplications is not guaranteed. question 1 what aspect of online learning, if any, has been most positive for you? question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? question 2 what aspect of online learning, if any, has been most negative for you? methods, limitations, and important considerations buena jill galleposo b.j.galleposo@leeds.ac.uk

to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? ensuring online activities are purposeful and practical reduce online activities especially those that cannot be translated properly into online (e.g., lab activities sometime do not translate well into online) provide more formative experiences to assess and ensure student understanding and difficulties to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? increasing flexibility in programme give students more options in picking their modules (e.g., allow them to choose modules outside of their school) to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? planning and distributing teaching schedule better distribute teaching evenly between online and in-person activities provide more hybrid synchronous options decrease lecture hours or provide more breaks during lectures to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? improving resource management and delivery streamlining online resources and hosting them in one place to make finding them more intuitive signposting and making students aware about the different resources available to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? improving communication between staff and students make module expectations explicit and clear have more than one means of communicating both online and offline (e.g., not just email) to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? providing help and guidance to support student digital literacy provide proper tutorials and guidance to support digital experience, especially before introducing a new platform and/or tool provide workshops and training for students to improve their digital literacy to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? providing academics with the proper training and support for the delivery of online learning have immediate and available it support for academics to rectify real-time issues as quickly as possible (e.g., moderators) provide workshops and training for academics to help familiarise themselves with the technology and platforms to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? improving the quality of technology and infrastructure ensure technology and platforms are working properly before using them invest in improving equipment and tools used for online learning (e.g., better mics) to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? having more student-centred practices and approaches in the online spaces encourage student engagement and collaboration amongst peers provide more interactive learning experiences to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? improving technical and it support increase the available devices to be loaned out to students and in the libraries faster and clearer communication with it when providing support to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? providing more accessible content utilise tools and features for accessibility such as closed captioning/subtitles use lecture capture tools to allow students who missed lectures due to unforeseen circumstances, as well as those who may need extra time to process information to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? having consistency across the different modules for each school have the same module structure in minerva for each module use the same technologies and platform total responses 512 # of faculties 4 # of questions analysed 3 question 1 what aspect of online learning, if any, has been most positive for you? question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? question 2 what aspect of online learning, if any, has been most negative for you? methods, limitations, and important considerations to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? (134 responses) be more consistent provide more accessible content improve technical and it support be more student-centred improve the quality of technology and infrastructure provide academics with the proper training and support for the delivery of online learning provide help and guidance to support student digital literacy improve communication between staff and students improve resource management and delivery plan and distribute teaching schedule better increase flexibility in programme ensure online activities are purposeful and practical

question 2 (194 responses) what aspect of learning online, if any, has been most negative for you? the increased propensity for off-task behaviours during online learning is one of the most recurrent responses. students in the faculty of environment typically find difficulties with focusing and concentration during online lectures, as it is easier for them to get distracted by external stimuli when they are not confined in physical classrooms. additionally, students reveal that online lectures, especially pre-recorded ones, to be less engaging and interactive which makes focusing an even harder task. due to these difficulties, students are also finding it difficult to find the motivation to actively engage in online learning. question 2 (194 responses) what aspect of learning online, if any, has been most negative for you? poor communication between staff, academic, and students is a persistent theme across the responses, wherein students recognise the barriers that online learning present towards effective and quick communication. this decrease in quality of communication consequently results in students feeling inadequately supported and unheard, as they feel that the communication online has been impersonal and delayed. additionally, the responses demonstrate two aspects to this theme: 1) technical issues, and 2) lack of empathy. for the former, students acknowledge that academics have little to no control over spotty communication resulting from technical issues. however, for the latter, responses reveal that students feel that academics need to empathise with the stresses and difficulties that students face with online learning. question 2 (194 responses) what aspect of learning online, if any, has been most negative for you? the second most common complaint regarding learning online is the lack of digital literacy and support for both staff and students. responses across the faculty highlight the need for more literacy support in the faculty of environment, arguing that the unfamiliarity with the technology and software as well as the improper usage of certain platforms lead to disruptions in learning. furthermore, the responses indicate that this lack of digital literacy from both academics and students make it difficult for students to navigate through their online learning environment successfully. with that said, a few of the responses also indicate that students feel that their technical issues are inadequately rectified, making them even more frustrated when faced with issues concerning digital literacy. question 2 (194 responses) what aspect of learning online, if any, has been most negative for you? according to the responses, impractical and unrealistic lessons (i.e., not reflective of real-life situations), poor collaboration and engagement within the learning environment, and the low engagement and interactivity in lessons have been the most negative aspects of online learning for the students in the faculty of environment. students in their responses express their frustration and disappointment towards the perceived poor practices and approaches, as they feel that their expectations are not being thoroughly met by the university they highly regard. question 2 (194 responses) what aspect of learning online, if any, has been most negative for you? zineldin et al. (2011) posit that the quality of resources and infrastructure is strongly linked to student satisfaction and this is properly demonstrated in this set of responses, as students argue that poor quality of lectures (e.g., unorganised lectures), materials, technology (e.g., laggy lectures resulting from poor wi-fi connection, poor digital technologies in libraries) have severely hindered their online learning experience. question 2 (194 responses) what aspect of learning online, if any, has been most negative for you? one of the primary concerns that students have regarding online learning are the negative effects it has on their physical and mental health, citing exacerbated feelings of loneliness, detachment, and isolation, as well as screen and eye fatigue as the main detriments to their learning experience. under this theme, responses also indicate the dehumanisation of online learning, in that students feel that they have been reduced to a “code.” total responses 512 # of faculties 4 # of questions analysed 3 question 2 question 1 what aspect of online learning, if any, has been most positive for you? question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? question 2 what aspect of online learning, if any, has been most negative for you? methods, limitations, and important considerations (194 responses) what aspect of learning online, if any, has been most negative for you? negative effects on mental and physical health low-quality learning resources issues with pedagogical approaches and practices lack of digital support and literacy poor communication amongst staff, academics, and students increased propensity for off-task behaviours during online learning

the second most identified theme from the responses is the convenience learning online has afforded for everyday living. simply put, students find that reduced travel cost and inconvenience (e.g., getting up early, long commutes) have been extremely positive for their learning experience. the increase and improvement in accommodations and adaptations for different learning needs and circumstances is the most recurrent and persistent theme across the responses from all the schools. under this sub-theme, recorded lectures, and accessibility features like closed captioning (cc) were the most frequently mentioned as the most positive aspect of learning online, as they helped all learners navigate through their learning, irrespective of the presence of a disability. furthermore, responses indicate that with the different accommodations and adaptations available, they are better able to adapt in cases of unforeseen circumstances like illnesses and family emergencies. lastly, responses also indicate that being able to accommodate to non-western practices (e.g., jewish sabbath) is an aspect of online learning that students appreciate. although many of the responses under this sub-theme refer to the safety that online learning has provided them in the context of covid, there were a few yet significant responses that discuss not only the physical aspect of safety but also the mental side of it. for instance, some of the responses under this theme talk about how the flexibility and accommodations that online learning has provided learners with has created a safe and comfortable learning environment for learners with disabilities and mental health issues. albeit one of the least frequent themes, it is still worth highlighting that increased connectivity was identified as a positive aspect of learning online in that responses imply that being able to connect readily to different places across the globe has a positive influence in one’s learning. one of the most frequent themes across the responses in all schools was the increased learner autonomy resulting from being able to manage and organise time more efficiently. many responses also indicate that the ability to choose when and how to learn according to what best fits the learner consquently helping students to take accountability and control over their own learning has been the most positive aspect of learning online. the ability to carry out different learning activities related to the course in different locations - whether the virtual or physical - that best suit the learner’s need at any point in time is a frequent them across all the schools in the faculty of environment. many of the responses attribute this flexibility in location to hybrid synchronous lectures. many of the responses across all schools point to the flexibility of study materials as one of the most positive aspect of online learning, in that online learning has increased the ease in which students can access materials . this flexibility is a result of resources being available anywhere and anytime, as well as the increased range in which these resources come in, such as pdfs, videos, images, and so on. a few responses from the school of food science and transport studies identified the digital learning tools employed in online learning, such as kahoot!, top hat, collaborate, and the chat functions in synchronous hybrid lectures, as the most positive aspect of online learning. a few responses from the school of geography indicate an appreciation for how online learning has encouraged staff and academics to improve existing practices, such as implementing a consistent structure across the different modules in the school of geography. on the other hand, as questions 2 and 3 demonstrate, the remaining schools recommend improving the consistency in their respective schools. multiple responses from the schools of earth and environment, food science, and geography express how the improvement in assessment during online learning has been the most positive for them, in that assessments have become more reflective of student capabilities, assess higher order of learning, and have been more valid and fair. total responses 512 # of faculties 4 # of questions analysed 3 question 1 what aspect of online learning, if any, has been most positive for you? question 3 to help you to learn effectively online, what one thing should we do? question 2 what aspect of online learning, if any, has been most negative for you? methods, limitations, and important considerations what aspect of learning online, if any, has been most positive for you? (184 responses) improved pedagogical approaches and technological infrastructures improved pedagogical approaches and technological infrastructures improved pedagogical approaches and technological infrastructures increased flexibility for students increased flexibility for students increased flexibility for students more accessible and student-friendly practices more accessible and student-friendly practices more accessible and student-friendly practices improved assessment experience flexibility in study materials safe and comfortable learning environment convenience for every day living more accommodations and adaptations for different learning needs flexibility in location increased learner autonomy increased connectivity better digital learning tools available encouraged schools and faculties to restructure and improve current practices

resource_data.description: References:

resource.title: Collis & Moonen (2010): Flexible Learning in a Digital World
Zineldin et al. (2011): Quality in Higher Education Assessing quality in higher education: New criteria for evaluating students' satisfaction
